Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: "AL MINBAR."
div.p: A few days ago we announced that the Sudan Government had prohbited the entry of "Al Minbar" to the Sudan, and in commenting on the fact we congratulated the Governmenon on the wisdom of its policy in that direction. As a sample of the dangerous character of some of our confrere's articles, we might recall the description of an interview (referred to in our issue of August 17) with an unnamed German gentleman, who, after asserting that England had raised the cry of fanaticism in order to frighten away Belgian, French, and German capital, and have a free hand in Egypt, reminded the Editor that the Engish had invented plague and cholera, etc., - an echo, this, of an Indian superstition which gave untold trouble to the Anglo-Indian Government. One cannot but wonder why Mr. Haflz Awad did not at once nail this fiction to the counter. Its propagatin by less scrupulous pens might esaily cause grave loss of life in an epideic year amoung the ignorant and superstitious. Should the population be previously inoculated with such a microbe - let us call it bascillus mendax antaglicus - a real epidemic would cause terrible devasation.

Another point - the eulogies of the Ottoman Empire. Now, we can quite understand that Mr. Awad, as a good Moslem, has a high opinion of th echaracter and abilities of the prssent Sultan of Turkey and a proper respect for a sovereign, who, however the doctors may debate, is the one oslem ruler who can claim to be de facto Khalif. But when we learn that the Armenians were instigated to rebel by British Consuls and missionaries, and that the Osmali Government of today is liberal, taxes lightly, and allows Jews and Christians to trade in peace, we begin to wonder whether Mr. Award had ever travelled in the Empire which he praises with such enthusiasm. A liberal governmen does not maintain th elegions of speies maintained by the Sultan, nor does it compe its sons to seek saftey in foreign lands, or reture for the good of their health to Aleppo (Mohmed Ali Bey), Damascus (Fouad Fasha), Diarbekir (Nouri Pasha) or to the salubrious plains of Arabia. A journey in Syria should convince Mr. Award of his error. Where will he be able to travel alon, and enjhoy immunity from theft or police annouane outisde the towns. Whu, on in the Mustessarifat of the Lebanon, a province practically independent of the Empire and reuled a Christian governor and a concil of Jews and Christians. But the Syrians, according to some of our Nationalists, are horrid, low-born creatures. Well, the Lebanon province is, as far as security goes, infinitely superior to anu province of the Ottoman Empire - not excepting Egupt - and thse turbulent wretches have the audacity ot be happier and freer than almost any of the other subjects of H.M. the "Khakan of the two seas." We hope Mr. Awad's rose-coloured pictures of the Turkeish Empire will not lead many of our young Egyptians to visit the country without most careful reconnaissance of the ground. Otherwise they may be locked up, as were half a dozen harmless visitors to the land of liberalism during the summer of 1905.

div.head: The Cherif Estates.
div.p: The Mixed Tribunal has appointed Mohamed Bey Rassim at judicial trustee of the late Cherif Pasha's estate.

div.head: Tha Plague.
div.p: An Italian child from Mohamed, Ali Square has been admitted into hospital at Alexandria. The boy has been isolated since the 6th inst.

div.head: New Rodah Bridges.
div.p: Tho construction of the now Nile bridges at Rodah is proceeding apace, and it is considered probable that their opening by the Khedive may take place next Febrnary.

div.head: Cairo French Agency.
div.p: The Prench Agency at Cairo announces that no details are to hand as to tho news of M. de la Booliniere's resignation. A letter from him, received four days ago, by M. de Valdrome, makes no reference to this matter.

div.head: Credit Fonder Hollandala.
div.p: The case of the Credit Foncier Hollandias, the illgeal issure of lottery bonds, came up for hearing on Satuday before the Tribunal of Contraventions, deputy Judge Zuki Ghali presiding. It was adjourned to the legal eighth day.

div.head: Fire in Ramieh.
div.p: Fire broke out in a house at Schutz Rameih, last night, and in the space of a few mintues the whole of the rooms were flames. The Fire Brigade had a hard task in extingushing the conflagration, the damage occasioned by which has not yet been estimated.

div.head: Government Schools.
div.p: Dr. Douglass Dunlop, Advisior to the Ministry of Education, in engaged in the preparation of a lengthy report on the instruction given and the results of the examination in the Government schools. This report will be presented to Lord Cromer on the letter's return from Europe.

div.head: Elopment.
div.p: A Greek youth of 22 years, who was in love with a Turkish girl of 16, eloped with his sweetheart a few days ago and no trace of them can be found. The girl's mother, however, believes that the amorous pair are still in Alexandria, and has appealed to the authorities to aid her in finding her child.

div.head: Vendetta.
div.p: As M. Yanni Bolas, nazir to M. Philippo Philippides, was leaving the latter's eeh, near the Delta Barrage, to prooeed to Menouf, he received a charge of buckshot from a gun, and fell dead on the spot. Three men have been arrested on suspicion of having committed the crime, which is ascribed to vengeance.

div.head: U.S.A. and Egypt.
div.p: A new Greek navigation company has been formed to ply steamers between Greece and the United States. The vessels will go direct from Piraens to America, without calling at intermediate ports. It is thought however that Egypt may take advantage of this new line to develop her commercial relations with the States, by transhipping at the Pirrens.

div.head: Sudan American Missions.
div.p: Our Suskin coresspondent writes that the Rev. Dr. Kelly Giffin arrived at Suskin from Khartoum on the 29th ult. and left for Port Sudan on the 1st inst. with a view to finding a suitable site for the establishment of a school. A girl's borading school will be ready next year at Khartoum and will be under the superintedence of Mrs. Kelly Giffin.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On October 6 and 7, 19 vessels of which 11 ere northward and 8 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 518,495.38 Of these 12 were Brtiish, 3 German, 1 French, and 2 Dutch. The toal receipts since October 1 are Fr. 1,851,248.01, and during that times 68 vessels transited the Canal, 32 being northward, and 36 southward bound.

div.head: Coptic Firest Converted.
div.p: Gummos Ibrahim, a priest of the Coptic Witron convent in the Behera province, has been converted to the Moslem faith. The conversion took place on Saturday at the Cairo Mehkemh Sharieh, and Gummos changed his name to Ibrahim RAghib. The lastest convert to Islamism is a Greek girl, of Alexandria who went thorugh the customary formalities before the Mehkemeh Sharieh in order to marry a native Moslem.

div.head: A Harem Romance.
div.p: An English translatino of Pierre Loti's romance of a harem, "Desenchantees," has just been published by Macmillan's Colonial Library under the title of "Dissenchated." This new novel by the celebrated French writer has been excellently Englished by Miss Clara Bell and is well worth reading especially by Anglos Egyptians as, although the scene is laid in Turkey, similar social conditions prevail here, which renders the work full of local "actuality."

div.head: Cotton Culture in Cerman Africa.
div.p: According to a recent Consular retun, the total productin of cotton in all the German Possessins in AFrica amounted to only 865 hales for the season 1905. The United States Vice Consul (Mr. N. C. Schlemmer, of Mannsheim) who furnishes the return, states that the German territory in African comprises an area near as large as the entire American cotton belt, and that the African natives do not remark to be able or willing to rise cotton at the present prices. "The cutlook for the production of cotton by the natives of Africa," he adds, "is far from encouraging."

div.head:
DISAFFECTION AT CAIRO.
ALARMIST REPORTS.
AUTHORISED CONTRADICTION.
div.p: We are authorised to state that the alarmist reposrts as to disaffection in Cairo which appeared a few days in some of the Londonnewspaper are quite devoid of foundation.

According to these statements, which emantaed from a Cairo correspondent of a daily paper, the Army of Occupation at Cairo was being held in extraordinary rediness to cope with any emergency that might arise, and a detailed account was being held in extraordinary readiness to cope with any emergency that might arise and a detailed account was given of the measuremes that were being taken.

It is perfectly true that a small force was held in immediate readiness to leave for Port Said at the time of the outbreak of the mutiny of the Syrian convicts on the trasnport Assya, and that this force remained underarms for two or three days. At present, however, no precautions, beyond those usual in all military centres where troops are congregated are observed, and we imagine that the newspaper correspondent who gave the news has mistaken outlying pickets for speical guards.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive came in from Montazah to Ras-el-Rin this morning, and granted a private audience to T.H. Prince Abbas Pasha Halim and Prince Kamal-ed-Din Pasha, his HIghness's brothers-in-law.
Tomorrow the Khedive will spend the day at Montzah Palace, and on Thursday morning will leave for Tantah to open the Agricultural Show there.
A Council of Minsiters will be held on Saturday next at Ras-el-Tin Palace under the presidency of the Khedive.
ON the same day H.H. Prince Jussein Pasha Kamel and Sir Reginald Wingate, the Sirdar, will have an audience of his Highness.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL LAW SCHOOL.
div.p: As already announced, M. Grandmulin has been appointed "Substitut in the Contentieux of the Finance Minsitry, with the salary attached to his previous post. According to the Mukattam, however, it is rumoured that the appointment is only for a year, that being the period of service to which M. Grandmoulin is still entiled in accordance with the terms of his contract.

In this connection our contemporary points out that no clause of the Anglo-French Agreement reserves the post of director of the Khedivial Law School to a Frenchman. At the most there exists between the Egyptian and Rrench Governments a tacit understanding that the post may be entrusted to a Frenchman in the event of a suitable Egyptian or Englishman not being found.

div.head: THE NATIONAL UNIVERSITY.
div.p: Four members of the Abasza family have together subscribed the sum of L.E. 700 for the proposed National University. Said Mohamed, a merchant of Gamaleih, Cairo, offers L.E. 1,500, Ali Bey Sherif, L.E. 300, Ali Bey Fahmi, L.E. 200, and Amin Bey El Asri, Sohag, Yousef Bey El-Moeilhi, Hanaefi Eff. Nagi, Cairo, and Ahmed Eff. Ramzi Assiout, have each subscribed L.E. 100,000 said to have been subscribed by Ali Pasha Fahmi. Ali Hakki, a pupil of the Kamel school and eight years of age has expressed his desire to subscribe P.T. 50.

div.head: MR. BLUNT'S ESTATE.
div.p: It is stated that Mr. Wilfrid Scawen Blunt is contemplating the sale of his estate of Matarieh.

Mr. Blunt is full of literary energy at the present time. In the October number of the "Independent Review" he again critixises Lor dCRomer, and urges "the nationlization of the civil adminstration of Egypt. This gentlemen also contributes to the forthcoming number of the "Dublin Review" a poem entitled "The Dance of Death," adapted with liverities, from Victor Hugo's Frantumes.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: The Egyptian sessions of his Majesty's Subreme Consular Court for the Dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Port will begin next month. Judfe Piggott is arriving about the middle of November. There are no important cases fown for hearing at Alexandria.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menepthah sailed from Malta yesterdays afternoon, and is due here on Friday at daybreak with passengers, mails, and general cargo.

The Khedivial mail steamship Prince Abbas will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Saturday and Port Said at 4 p.m. on Sunday for Beyrout, Tripoli, Mersina, Alexandretta, Larnaca, Limessol, Caiffa, and Jaffa.

div.p: EGYPTIAN ARMY OUTFITS A SPECIALITY.

div.head:
PLAGUE AT SUEZ.
RESOLUTIONS OF THE CONSULS.
div.p: The meeting of the Consuls at Suez respecting the outbreak of plague took place last Thursday evening, under the presidency of Mr. Th. Meyer, Germans Consul. The meeting was attended by the vice Consuls of Italy, France, Russia, Greece, and the acting vice Consuls for Austria Hungary; and it was decided to submit the following resolutions to Dr. Creswell, sanitary inspector of the town: -
I. - The Consuls ought to be kept informed at least once a week of the healthy of the town, and of the cases of plauge which occur.

II. - The Europeans attacked by plague inhabiting houses which can be easily isolated and guarded by the Sanitary authorities, to be treated in their own houses, which is in conformity with Art. 2 and 3. of the Khedivial decree dated 27 May 1899 No. 399.

III. - The conveyance of European cases of plague whose houses are not adapted for isolation and surveillance must be done in a more suitable manner, by all means avoiding the unfit conveyance by the usual cart.
IV. - The applicatin of the second paragraph of Art. I. of the above mentioned decree concerning the advices to the Consuls msut be regularly executed.

VI. - That, as already suggested by Dr. Creswell, a Consular represntative must be allowed to visit the isolation huts from time to time, and examine the manner in which the patients are treated, and how the service is organised.
Since last week a considerable decrease of plague at Suex in shown, and this is owing to the strict measures of disinfection and isolation.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SUCCESSOR.
div.p: The American newspaper obtain some remarkable information about Egupt. The London correspondent of the New York. "American" telegraphed recently to that newspaper as follows: -

There is some likelihood of Lord Kitchener succeeding Lord Cromer as the adminsitrator of Egypt. Lord Cromer has been anxious for some time to leave Egupt and take a thorough rest from public affairs. He is said to be warmly in favour of the appointment of Lord Kitchener as his successor, as in some measure he had the education of the present commander-in-chief while the latter was in Egypt.

Lord Kitchener is proving a source of embarrassment to the Government. What is to be done with him is a perplexing question to the heads of state. His term of command in India has not much more time to run, and if Lord Kitchener is averse to taking control of Egyptian affairs there is a likelihood of his command there being extended. It is very clear that if he is allowed to come home that an outcry will be raised if he is not at once given something fitting for him to do.
One rumoour current is that he will succeed General Lyttleton at the head of the Army Council.

div.head: EGYPT AND CENTRAL EUROPE.
div.p: The new Continental express service between Egypt and Central Europe is to begin shortly.

Particularly importance is attached by Germany to the working of this express, which will have its starting point in Berlin, and its terminus at Naples, where it will fit is with a service of fast German steamers for Alexandria. There is reason to believe that the German delegates to the International conference brough great pressure to bear to secure the establishment of this service, which is openly regarded as an effort to place Germany's traffic communications with Northern Africa on a more secure and permanent basis than has never before been possible.

Commencing on Oct. 23 the Oceana is to engage in fortnightly sailings from Genoa and Naples to Alexandria, and after Jan. 8 she is to run weekly between Naples and Alexandria. The Oceana the aforetime Union-Castle liner Scot, which was once lengthened by her former owners, and has now began practically record structed at great cost by Messrs. Hagland and Wolff of Belfast, is declared to be at the present moment one of the best fitted and most comfortable boat afloat. The Oceana is to do the passage from Naples to Alexandria in sxty six hours.

Germans never do anything halves. In connection with this new service from Italian ports to Egypt the Hambur American Line running a train delux from Berlin, and the distances from the German capital to Alexandria will be covered by rail and boat in less than 106bhours. Moreover, the company will send conductors right thorugh from Berlin to Cairo to look after passengers and their baggage. It may also be mentioned, as another example of German enterprise, that the Norddentscher Lloyd Company have arranged to despatch the Kaise Wilhelm der Grosse from New York on January 26, to convey American passengers direct to Alexandria. This is quite a new departure on the aprt of the Norddeutscher Company. This Atlantic greyhound will probably be the fastest steamship going to Egypt this winter, but the White Star liners Cedric and Celtic, whch are also to run from New York to Egypt, will be the biggest. Ever since Egypt became popular as winter resort there has never been such a show of fine steamers as is promised this year in connection with the transit of American visitors.

div.head:
THE ISIS MISHAP.
ANOTHER PASSENGER'S ACCOUNT.
div.p: A well-known member of the British Colony at Cairo gave our representative the following interesting account of the accident: -

The Isis left Brindi at about 2.39 a.m. on the 1st inst. in fairly rough weather. Nothing of interest occurred for the first nine hours of the voyage, and few passengers were on deck at noon when the accident occurred. Suddently a loud jarring noise, accompanied by considerable vibration and a sensation that the ship had been suddenly and violently wrenched, was notices. The noise and vibration were caused by the starboard engines, which "raced" on the detachment of the screw and by the explosion of the cover of the corresponding cylinder cover just below the smoking saloon. The cylinder was wrecked, and the graments of the cover were only prevented from entering the smoking room by the interpoisitino of one of the iron beams of the ship's frame. None of the elss the shook was considerable. Two marble tables in the middle of the room, one of which had just been vacated were destroyed, their iron supports being wrecked while the marble tops were flung several feet into the air and smashed on the floor, to the natural surprise of several passengers who were smoking or reading - fortunately at the other side of the room. All keep their heads. The boats were got ready and the chief engineer, who was standing by the throttle at the moment, shut off steam at once, thus preventing the accident from attaining more serious proportions. The pomps were put together and got to work and the Captain after learning of the loss of the screw and the accident to the cylinder gave ordres to proceed to Zante witth remaining screw. At about 2 p.m. on the 1st inst. the Austrian Lloyd boat was passed and the news signalled. The Isis continued her course till about 5 p.m. when the bessel was still taking in more water than was safe and the Captain decided to put in to Zante, where the vessel arrives at sunset. On the following day the passengers went on shore and found the island so pleasant and interesting that they did not greatly regret the accident.

Meantime the leak had to be stopped. No driver could be found at Zante and the leak could not be stopped from withing owing to the amount of water that had entered the hold. Two officers of the Isis then entered the water with a wedge shaped block of wood and succeeded after some hard work in running it into the leak greatly checkin ghte in flow of water.

On Wednesday the 3rd inst., H.M.S Suffolk appeared having been ordered up from Malts. Divers were sent to the Isis, and examined the leak which was finally patched up after 14 hours work - from 6 p.m. on the 3rd inst. to 8 a.m. on the 4th.

At 10 a.m. on the 4th inst. the Isis left Zants accompanied for a short distance by H.M.S. Suffolk which ten returned to Malts. For the rest of the voyage the weather was excellent and the vessel reached Port Said at 2p.m. on Saturday last having averaged nearl,y 14 knots with her reamining sorew all the way from Zante. An address to the Captain and officers of the ship who showed great coolness and presence of mind thorughout was presented by the passengers on the evening of the 3rd inst.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, - I should like to endorse the opinoin of your correspondent in your issue of 6th inst., viz, that the accident to thos steamer, which was so near costing many human lives and which has caused all business people in Egupt and elsewhere so much inconvience be thorougly investigated as mich as Government offical as by the owners of th steamer. It is rumoured that the wrecked engine was well known to be out of order by those on boad before the vessel left Brindisi; therefore the conclusion come to by people on shore is that had the engine been "shut down" in time the accident would have been averted. I beg to remain dear Sir - Yours obediently.
Another Enquirer

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLICY FOR CUBA.
div.p: The British position in Egypt has always had a great interest for President Roosevelt and the course of policy and action suggested by it willin all probability be followed in Cuba. This is believed will be found to be the safest policy to pursue in view of the political situation at home. The American people are to be assured that the country is to obtain all the advantages of annexation without serious risk and without hurting the susceptibilities of patriotic Cubans who will still see the flag of their Republic floating side by side with the Stars and Stripes.This will be the line taken by the Administration in Congress.

div.head: COTTON.
div.p: The following Liverpool telegram has been received from Messrs. Collinge Brothers: -
We think it is a good time to buy. We think present prices safe; even if the market should go temporarly lower.

div.head:
MR. BLUNT'S PAMPHLET.
A CRITCISM
div.p: A correspondent write: - As far as literary style goes Mr. Blunt's little pamphlet has the unquestioned merit that one expects to find the work of an expert man of letters: Exordium, perportation, and disposition in general are faultless and well phrased.

As a pamphlet - well, the key, the suprising revelaiton is contained in one phrase "an appeal to my countrymen." We know Mr. Blunt's former ways of thinking; how, long ago, he was even imprisoned for his actions in Irish questions and how in the eghties he suported Arabi, how, in a word, he was a Nationalist and Anti English. And so when we saw the title "Atrocities of British Rule in Egypt" we expected brilliant, bitter invective, strkiking at the heart of England's whole foreign and colonial plicy: we though to find a foe whom we could oppose and even respect.

But alas for Mr. Blunt. He has left the rankf of the emeny and ranged himself with the merly disployal. Even for Arabi's affair he now posses as a mediator mitigating the wrath of England. He gives a word or two in Egypt. And the "astrocitites" themselves these overwhelming and "humanity-staggering" charges, which were to convulse the ORient, and hurl Greater England, brutal, unworthy, back to her owen crim-stained shores. We find four or five - statistics: that is the only word. We are told what the witness said, what the judge and others thought meant, what someone hinted to Mr. Blunt's, what Gladston - of all people! - thought he would have done if something or other had been confirmed. We fin a vague account of a man being executed in Alexandria for killing two Englishmen , a misty reproduction of the Meushawi case, and, of course, Denishwai. Beyond the extract from a French report of the executions, the chief items seems tot be Mr.Blunt's wonder at a witness (who had been more than once to Denishwai) identifying 29 men. That reminds us of the Virgilian pig and litter. 30 in a litter was a sign of poeteic license, a prodigy. No one would have boggled at 29. The pamplet ends with an appeal to the world in general to arraign Lord Cromer, but apparently the only ground of impeachment is Mr. Blunt's verson of the Denishwai incident. We looked for the birth of a mountainous. We looked for the birth of a mountainous Jehad. Forth comes a bedraggled, semi would be patriotic mouse cheeping of - statistics!

The pamphlet will of course do some harm in England. A clever Frenchwomen, in comparing England and France, says that the foreign policy of England is as mean and petty as her home policy is broad and efficient. Exactly, the meanness and pettiness, the snares, and the attempts to hamper, are all devised by Englishmen for Englishmen : they interpret party government and individual criticism to mean division in the camp. They deplore with tearful seal to "tyrannical hidebound officialdom," the "brutal and licenticus soldiery." It is quaint, almost pathetic, to watch Liberals in power, forced against their will to cope with foreign unrest and difficulties, after so many year's lack of practice, but it becomes rather a source of wondering contempt to see the ways of the indiviudal critics. Some are, of course, to be excused; they always have found a certain excuse. A Labour member who has not found a place in a Cabinet, and under secretary who must hasten, before it is too late, to carve his name in the annals of the nation, a rabid Atheist sending reminders to the Deity whose thunderbolts failed to greet his last outburst - all these must try to make their mark. And how else can they achieve this. ONe wild speech or letter is so easy a method, and England is so indulgent! If one is abroad there are always consuls, and police, and others to save one from any danger.

But so many others, well educated people at that are taking to this species of critism. We have called its disloyalty, but perhaps it is only a sympton of excessive sensibility. In many - perhaps the majority - it is, in a sense, advertisement; they are the "half ones," the second generation, in transition from their bourgeois fathers to the real class with which they mix. And it is a dinstinct proof of culture to be able to criticise fluently, if inaccurately, all things at home and aborad. It is mistaken for bold and unflinching truth to take the part of any one white or coloured, against one's own countrymen; and besides, investigation is so laborious, the accounts of people who know natives and such tings are so hard to believe, so unlikely. It is so humilitaing to have to confess that one does not know everything, especially when one has just been explaining things to some indulgent foreigner who wonders why on earth the English cannot stand by one another!

It is of little use proclaiming that all these people, and all their disloyal criticisms, weaken our rule, and put us in a false position towards those we rule, and it is false position towards those we rule, and it is still less profitable taking them seriouslu; besides, one can't no one can, read such pamplets as the "atrocities" seriously, any more than one could read a schoolboy's criticism of a philosophy book. One has to avoid and disown them as one would some luckless street ranter who knows no better.

We can at least hope for one result, and that is that Messrs. Blunt Byles, Keir-hardie, Roberston, and their like have achieved the one thing that sometimes is effective (when love of England has no effect), namely, "bad form," instead of reown, as the culmination of their little pamphlets, tracts, letters, and speeches. Mr. Gladston used to write postcards, but then he has so much to do, - translations of Horonce, commentaries on the Vulgate and such things, besides ordinary work.

There is some hope when we can show these worthy critics that repudiation has taken the place of serious criticism, and that their most violent outbursts are met, in the last extremity, by the police court instead of a trail for high tresson. Mr. Blunt's delighted panegyric in the "Times" shows how they all treasure the least evidence of serious notice. They know they don't deserve it, and the last word we need say of them, of the pamphlet, and of Mr. Blunt himself, is the old Horatian line, "dilapasm in cineres facem," - as Mr. Gladstone himself rendered it, "Once a flambean now an ash."

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Hassan Pasha mohensen, who arrived at Alexandria yesterday by the Austrian Lloyd's S.S. Semiramis from Trieste has greatly benefitted in health during his long stay in Europe. Has been taking the water at Ems.

It appear likely that the choice of a tutot for the children of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim will fall on Hussein Pasha Fehmy, ex commandant of the Khedivial yacht Mahroussa and curator of Prince Ahmed Seif El Din, who is the brother of the late Prince Ibrahim.

The Salsomaggiore correspondent of the Paris edition of the "New York Herald" reports that though Prince Ibrahim and his daughters are giving no entertainments and attending no functions on account of the recent daeath of Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, they had tea with the Duchess of Medina Mme. John Balli, Mme and Miles. Sasson, Mme. Antoine Vissto, and Mme. Constantindi by invitation of M. Ugo Luzzato.
El Mirali Hawker Bey. Governor of the Red Sea Provinces returned to Suskin from Erkoweit on the 1st.
Mr. Courtenay Clitton, chief inspector of the Buildings Department, has obtained two months' leave.
Mr. Tottenham, inspector of Sudan Irrigations, has obtained a month's sick leave.
Mr. W. H. Bailey, inspector of bridges Sudan Government Rail ways, Suakin has obtained one month's leave of absence, which he will spend in Cairo.
Lieut R.E. Platt, R.A., specting Ordance Officer, who succeeded Lieut. Cunningham, when the latter went home on sick leave, is not proceeding on leave as previously announced.

The Marquis Salvgo Raggi will probably arrive in Cairo early in November to present his letters of recall. It is probable that the new Agent, Commander Giulio Malmusi, will arrive at the same time to take up his appointment.
Mgr. Dairan Maronite Archbishop of Tarsus, who has been definitely appointed Patriarchal Vicar of the Maronite community of Egypt's expected in Cairo about the end of the month.
Judge Ahmed Khalid Bey of the Alexandria Native Court has asked to be allowed to retire on pension.
Hamid Bey Sidki, Recruiting Department, and Sigh Hassan Effendi Ahmed, Medical Department have been retired on pension.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh: Mr. H. Devonshire, Mr. and Mrs. L. Dents, Dr. and Mrs. A. Kautzky bey and family, Mr. G. Grill, Mr. Jules Fonder, Mr. and Mrs. C. Bow, Mr. W. Delanoy, Miss L. Phillips, Mr. James Watson, Mme A. Levy and family, Mr. S. Bridson, Mr. A. Smith, Mr. Sidney Simpson, Mr. and Mrs. L. Gilbert., Miss H. Kent.

div.head: EXCAVATIONS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The numerous parties of explorers and excavators will soon again be arriving in the Nile valley. Mesers. Grenfell and Hunt were so successful in their finds of papyri in the Fayoum that they will certainly return there again, and the same may be said of Dr. Naville and Mr. Currelly at Deir el Bahari; whilst Professor Petrie may be expected to bivouac somewhere in the Delta Mr. Andrews, who came out for a third time last spring to search for paleontological remains upon the paltean to the West of Medinet-el-Fayoum secured some most valuable fossils; those found last season being in several cares much more perfectly preserved than previously was the case. The whole skull showing th ecomplete dentition and arrangement of the tusks of the Arsinoitherium is now completely known, and a restoration of it may now be seen in the Natural History Museum at South Kensington. It is strange that France and Germany do not turn their attention to the abundant fossil remains in this district which undoubtedly possess specims that will go far to fill up the gaps of prehistoric natural history. No collection can be complete without specimens of there strange ancestors of the hippopotami and elephants, and it must be remembered that in the "mummified fauna of Egypt" we also have the best preserved skeletons of animals contemporary with the earliest civilization of the human race.

div.head: Circularie H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres a baisse, vendredi passe, de 1/4 a 4 1/8 pour'cent; mais il est remonte le lendemain a 4 3/8 ton cours precedent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a baisse de 1/8, vendredi, a 86 1/8 et est demenure a ce prix de jour auivant. L'Unifiee est restee invariee a 104 1/4. La National Bank a perdu 1.8 vendredi pour le rattraper asmedi a 28 7/8 L'Agricule es restes inchangee a 9 3/4 de meme que la Daira a 16 3/4 et la Delta Light a 11 5/8.
A Paris l'action Credit Founcier Egytien a e' octure samedi en reprise de 1 franc a 779. Le Banque d'Athenes a ete stationnaire a 145.
Les fonde russes continnent etre fermes. A Paris, l'emprunt 1906 a passe avant heir de 81.60 a 32.50, et a Loudres de 78 ¼ a 79 1/4
Ice, le marche des valeurs a montre, ce matin, de bonnes dispostitions et la plupart de prix pratiques sont en avance sur ceux de la closure de vendredi dernier.

Le National Bank que cous avions laisses a 26 ½ a avance a 26 11/16 et la Cassa di Sonton a 227-228. Le Comptoir Financier s'est inscrit a 6 ¾. La Barque d'Orient a ete mienux tenue a 130-131. La Banque d'Abysainie s'est alourdie a 5 9/16-3/8.

A Credit Foncier est reste a 775; la part de fondatenur a gague 10 frances a 960. La Nile Land a atteint les abords de 16 pur fioir a 15 7/8. L'action Enterpirse and Development a ete ferme a 12 ¾ et la part de fondateur a 21 7/8. Le Warden Estate et l'Union Fonciero ont perdu respectivement 1/16 a 6 7/8 et 6. Les Improvements ete demandera 5 11/6. Les parts de fondateur Entreprises Immobheres et Travaux ont cloture aux environs de 80.
La part de fundateur Agricole du Nil a hausre a 8 5/8. Les part de fondatuer Allot ment a ete traitee a 126 127.
Les Joussances Eauz du Caire se sont consolidees a 264. La Frizorifque ont progreesure a 6 1/8 et la part de fondateu a 10 ¾.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hotelieres, les Nungovich sont restes a 17 ¼ 5/6. Les Eguptian on faibi a ¼ 5/16 et les Upper Egypt a 5.
Parmi les petites valenres les Dalta Land Sont remontes a 3 7/16 et les Hooker a 1. Les Estates ont ete echanges a 1 13/16 7/8; a part de fondatuer a debute a 11 9/16 pour terminer a 11 13/16 7/8.
La Bourse d'Alexandrie a repis avant heir ses seances du samedi. Celle de Caire en fera problemeant antant des asmedi prochain.
Le séance d'avant hier a Alexandria a ete calme, mais ferme. La National Bank a gagre prea de 3/16 a 26 13/16. La Nile Land a avance 1 16. Les Delta Land ont remonte a 3 3/8 7/16.

La penuri d'or locale dont nour avons parle vendredi passe tire a sa fio. Des avant hier le gouvernement a mis la disposition de la National Bank one partie des disponibilites du Tresor ce qui a mene une certaine detente.

En outre 1,700,000 sont attendues de Loudres en Egypte d'ici lundii prochain, ce qui, avec le paiement des coupons de la Dette privilegiee (15 Octobre conrant) aura, assurement, pour effet de retablir la situation normale.
Nous detachons d'une lettre de Loudres en date du 1er Octobre le passage suivant:

"La situation du marche monetaire continue a tenir le Stock Exchange dans une inuction relatives. Les fonds britann ques ne peuvent reprendre seriusement le chemin de la hausse tant qu'ils ne recebront pas l'implusion que leur donne l'abondance de l'argent. La demande d'or de la part des Etats Unis s'est, il est wradralentie, mais elle n'a pas cesse. L'opinion prevaut a tort ou a raison qu'il pourrait y avoir une racreud cence car les besoins de New York ne seraient pas encore satistsfaits. On annonce toutefoi que le secre aire du Trevor, M. Shaw va deposer 26 milliond de dollars dans les Banques de differentes villes des Etats Unis. Ces depues aeront rembourses quant la tension mone air actuelle sera passion probablement fin Janvier 1907.

Ici, les coupons d'Octobre vont sans donte apporter une certaine aissance; mais il ne faut peut etre pass attendre a une detente pronouncee d'ici quelque temps, cest a dire avant que l'on soit dixesur l'eststreel du marche americain.

On nous prie de demntir la rumeur mis en circulation ces jours derneirs soivant l'quelle l'Egyptian Improvement Corportaion aurilacquirs le terrain de 12,000 metres carres airtre derrie e la propriete Giausclis, a Kasar-el-Aisi et serait aur le point de le revendre a un groupe a des conditions avantagenses.

On announce de Bruxelles que le conseil d'adminsistration de la Societe des Tramway electrique du Caire a arrete le dividende a proposer par action de jouissance a Frs. 22,50 countre Fres. 16 l'annee derniere.
Les recattes de la Dalta Light Railways Co. pour la semaine an 29 Septembre se sent evee a Li.E. 5,083 contre 4,337 en 1905 soit e augmentation de L.E. 746.
Les recettes totales depuis le ler Avirl 19 6 ont atteint L.E. 102,994 contre 94,247 en 1903, soit en plus value de L.E. 8,747 pour l'exercise courant.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd hui a midi et demie.)

L'Agricole, la National Bank, les Nungovich Hotels, les Estates et le Comptoir ont surtout attire l'attentino, mais de facon genereale le affaires demeurent claireemees. On attend d'umoment a l'autre le courant d'activite qui se produit habituellement vers cette epoque.

Volci quelles sont les fluctuations d'anjour d'hoi: les jourssances Eaux du Caire montent de 263 a 264 la Behera de 36 5/8 a 36 ¾, les Markets de 25/9 a 26/6. les Obligation Credit Foncier Egyptian de 336 ½ a 337 ¼, l' Anglo-American Nile de 5 3/8 a 5 13/32, le Nungovich Hotels de 17 5/16 a 17 ½, l'ordinary Khedivial Mail de 34/6 a 34/7 ½, les Estates de 1 27/32 a 29/42, le Comptoir de 63/4 a 6 27/32 l'ancienne et de 6 ½ a 6 9/16 la nonvelle, les Buildings Linds de 4 13/16 a 4 15/16, la Banque d'Orient de 130 a 131 et le Credit Franco-Egyptian de 5 ¼ a 5 9/32.

Par contre, la D.Ira est offerte a 36 8/4, les dividendes Biere du Caire flechissent de 65 a 64; la Casea di Sconto de 228 ½ a 227 ¾ l'ancienne et de 222 ¾ a 222 ¼ la nouvelle, I'Investment est offert a 1 3/16 et l'Union Fonciere a 6 livres.
Tels sont les changements qu'on releve sur la cote, mais ils n'ont qu'une valeur relative car plusieurs de ces valeurs n'ont nome pas ete traitees.

div.head:
"OPEN DOOR" IN FAR EAST.
OCCUPATION OUTSIDE MUKEN.

div.p: Japan reduses to accept a new reservation for foreign occupation outside Mukden as equivalent to opening the city to foreigners. All the commerical power support Japan in her demands. (Rueter)

div.head: SYMPATHY WITH THE DUMA.MEMORIAL FROM 300 M.P's.

div.p: A deputation will start for St. Petersburg on Friday in order to present a memorial to the ex President of the Duma. The signatories include 300 Members of Parliament. Doubts are expressed in St. Petersburg as to the opourtuness of this visit. The reactionary Press is loud in denunciation o fthe scheme, and declares that small pity would be felt if the victories fell victims to the "black hundred gangs." (Reuter)

div.head:
SIR ROBERT HART'S STATUS.
FOREIGN CONTROL OF CUSTOMS.

div.p: Sir Robert Hart has issued circulars tot he foreign colony declaring that his status is unchanged. and that he is satisfied that there will be no undue interference with the foreign control of the Customs. (Rueter)

div.head:
THE NEWFOUNDLAND FISHERIES.
ERRONEOUS AMERICAN VERSIONS.

div.p: It is reported that the Minisitry following the example of Natal intends to resign as a protest against the modus vivendi concluded by England with America. (Rueter)

It inauthoritatively stated that the indignation expressed in Newfoundland is due to erroneous American versions of the modusvivendi Newfoundland was consulted throughout the negotiations and the suggestion that her claims were overlooked is unwarranted. (Rueter)

div.head:
ACTIVITY IN ST. PETERSBURG.
FURTHER BOMB OUTRAGE.

div.p: Bombs were thrown at Vice Governor of Kazan and the Commander of the garrison of Sebastopol. Both of them have been wounded. The assassin have escpaed.
Continued activity here on the part of the police results in the almost daily discoveries of bombs and ten pounds of dynamite were found in the possession of a girl student. (Rueter)

div.head:
SOUTH MANCHURIAN RAILWAY.
JAPAN'S EFFECTIVE CONTROL.

div.p: The "Times" learns from Peking that the disinclination of China to participate in the South Manchurian Railway Company leaves Japan in affective control of the south Manchuria. (Rueter)

div.head:
SULTAN AND FANATIC.
SAHARAN SORCERER WELCOMED.

div.p: The Sultan has taken under his protection a bien fanatical sorcerer named Maelain, who his followers have arrived at Marakeh, they assulted several Europeans included two Germans. By the orders of the Sultan the officials have placed themselves at the disporal of Maelain. (Rueter)
At the Congress of Constitutional Democrats M. Milioukoff declared that passive resistance was incompatible with the forthcoming elections. (Havas)
The Parisian bakeries were closed all yesterday in virture of the Sunday Closing Act. The supply of bread was provided for. (Havas)
Mr. S.T. Evans has been returned unoppossed for Mid Glamorganshire. (Rueter)

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsbiel for the opinions expressed by our coresspondents in a spirit of fair play to all to permit - within certain necessary limits free discussion.

div.head: OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir.—There seems to have been a good deal of plain speaking, and bad feeling in the correspondence in your columns are "Offieials and Civilians," but for real downright snobbism commend me to the letter of October 5, purporting to be written by one who has been educated at Cambridge. To my mind it seem incredible that such a letter should have been written by a member of that liberal and distingusihed Univerrity. I was especially taken by your correspondent's expresion "studied irony," by which he hoped to compass the "toleration" of the unofficial community. Perhaps your correspondent keeps a stock of carefully selected sarcastic remarks to inflict on his "commerrical" acquaintances. I would advise him for his own safety to reasort to "silent contempt." I do not think they would "tolerate" studied irony very long. The tarbush, Sir, is an outward and visible sign of our bodily service, not of our social standing, even though it may have to be made larger to suit a "swollen head."
With apologies for intrusion on yonr valuable space, - I am, dear Sir,
Yours etc.,

div.head: OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir,—I deeply regret, that I, as a member of the ordinary low down commercial class of Cairo, should be such a cause of annoyance to Cantab & Co., cream the of British Isles. At the same time 1 am truly grateful on behalf of my offending brethren that they should condescend to recognise as fellow-countrymen, or even tolerate us on this earth at all. We atand in awe of "the studied irony" which will keep us from becoming too familar with the high and mighty tarbush aspiring section of the community - for this small mercy we are again grateful. By all means let them wear the tarbush, or I beg to suggest, as their aim in life is to be distinguished from the "common herd," that they should be dumbered and wear a badge like the donkey boys. Then we wonld not fail to recognise them and duly tremble in tho presence of a Government employe. "Cantab" must not run away with the idea that the British business man is at all anxious to cultivate the acquaintance of his class,or that is be discussing an inferior animal. Both business man and official are the necessary evils of civilisation, and I beg to remind the latter that he is dependent upon commorce for his position and his salary.
Apologising for taking op your valuable time, I remain, etc.

div.head: OFFICIALS AND CIVILIANS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Sir,—The following remarks may perphas prove an adequate reply to the letter from Mansoursh in your issue of 4th ist.
It passes comprehension why your baluable columns should be utilised as a "draw" (for badgers) or fish pond for "bait" by one of these fishballs.

I submitt that if any person every stood self-convicted of snobbism, the indiviudal who signs himself "Cantab" stands in that position for all the outrageous effusions, which have ever appeared in any paper his for conerted puppyism and arrogance, will take a leading place. I pass his letter by with the scorn and utter contempt which it deserves merely asking where would England's greatness he were is not for her commerical men.

It begins to be accepted fact with him and his compeers that there is actually such a title as civlian offical, but it can only exist in imagination as all belong to the common herd. With this letter I take leave of the subject, as I consider it ijura dig. to enter the list with opponents who seem prepared to advance any theory or statement in support of their animadversions principally to cover their own snobbish behavior and like the frog in the fabie will swoll out until they burst. - I am your truly.

div.head: BASTA BEY'S SCHOOL.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir. - Whenever the came of this school is mentioned before any com munity of people of high rank, there appears to the minds of such, the benevolent act, which was given to the Egyptian nation, through the education of her children by the founder of the school late Basta Bey. It is found on one of the healhiest spots of Sohag, and it constains about 450 students of different creeds. As to the fame of its success it is widely spread even among those who did not see the school; for no means of mental, physical, or moral training is ever neglected. But as benevolence cannot be limited in one person, we also admire and highly appreciate the great deed of Dr. Dimitri, who, freedly offered to visit the school once a week, and examin the students who happen to be sick at any time.
Would a very samll proportion of the Egyptians try to resemble these two great persons in acts of courtesy we would never feel a backward nation. - I remain, Sir,
Your Respectfully,
N. Ghabrial.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

This week has shown no easing off in the money position, and the Bank return reveals a decrease of the reserve to 42 7/5 % being 41% lower, but this compares well with the position last year. The news comes from Washington of 26 million dollars being distributed by the United States Treasuary among the prominent Banks in America, which showes clearly that Scretary Shaw realises the necessity for action and the best posted men in this market area convinced that he will interfere to prevent any unnecessary stringency. Besdies this, the regular large receipts of gold £1,900,000 being just now on the way are a great relief. In fcat, while there seems no real reason to predict a squeeze all are thinking it might happen and the fear produces excessive caution. Each year the Autum demands upset more and more the market expectations and money is not likely to move down to present.
The Stock Markets.

In so frequently alluding to the stagnant condition of the stock markets wer are consciou of the risk of incurring the stigma of being classed as pressimists, but to accurately describe the prevailing state of affairs it is impossible to be optimisitc. The marked absence of public business is a matter which has troubled members of the Stock Exchange for a considerable business is a matter which ha troubled members of the Stock Exchange for a considerable tome and unfortunately there are no real signs of a permanent improvement. In times when there has been some substantial cause for depression such as war or rumours of war members have buoyed themselves up with the hope that with a clearing of the political atmosphere a return to active shars dealing was inevitable. Since the settlement of the Morocoo imbroglio they have waited in vain for the business which is conspicius by its continued absence. The plain fact is thtat in the main the public have withdrawn their support and refuse all invitation to return. Various reasons are given for this, but none of these brings comfort to the stock brokers. It seems evident that with the remarkable improvement in the trade of the country, investors are more and more diposed to sink their capital in commerical enterprises from which at one time they kept a safe distance.

No more striking example of the fitful state of the markets is to be seen than in their extreme susceptibility to passing rumours favorable or otherwise. The suspicion of an adverse influence is sufficient to put prices down to the lowest levels while a fourable report will have the effect of spending them up to a point which it is impossible for them to maintain for more than a few hours sometimes not even for one hour.
The account just concluded revealed a deplorable replace in quotation on the previous making up which were then sufficently depressed.

This week dealers have been have occupied with the details of the settlement and the little new business has been carried on. It would appear that the drain of gold from the Bank is nearing an end, and, morever, it is annoutced that Mr. Shaw has come to the aid of the New York money market. This added to the fact that the Bank rate has not been further raised as earlier in the week it was feared would be necessary has served to cast a cheerful ray around the "House," and the tone today is better.
Consults.

The more cheerful view now taken of the future of money and the non increase of the Bank rate have caused a distinct hardening of the gilt edged market and Consols yesterday gained 1/8. They have further advanced today, being how quoted 86 11/14

The Hon. Jefferson Levy of the Untied States has been making some intersting observatoins regarding Great Britain's supremier securities and he was inclind to blame the Government for permitting these to be so depressed. He suggested that the Government ought to finance these stocks so as to put them above par. If this was not desirable he thought Consol might be issued in small denominations and allowed to go into circulation as money - American finance, which is not likely to find acceptance here.
Foreign Bonds.

The present quiescent stae of affairs in Russia and the revivial of confidence in Paris in Russian finances have brought a speculative deamand for the fonds of that country. The new have been in special requiet and the discount on the new loan has been reduced to 9 discount. The Fours close 73 1/6. Japanese stocks have been inclined to sag, but they are firmer today. It is believed that the balance of the new Four per cent loan and the redemption of the Sixes will not now effected until the New Year and this is apparently to some extent the reason for the set back. Rumours regarding the grave condition of the health of the Sultan depressed Turkish bonds, and the Turkish United lost 1/3, but yesterday there recovered ¼.
Hom Ralls.

Threatned labour troubles have assisted in keeping this market in the dupms and a satisfactory batch of traffic returns failed to impart any animation. The Scotch stocks were at one time particularly depreseed on account of the Clyde boiler marker's strick, but more hopeful news from that district was subsequently reported, as a result of whch Faledonian Deferred put on under the influence of the Grantham diaster, and the Deferred which have been irregular close about ¾ lower on the week. It is satisfacory to note a more cheerful tone today improvements of 1/8 to ½ having been distrivuted among the list.
Americans.

The troubles in Cuba have been weakening influence in the American railway market, and although there was something of a revivial yesterday on more cheerful news from New York rumpours of a destructive flood at New Orleans caused another setback. In nearly all cases prices showed substantial reductions on the week. The market opened firm this morning, however, on the announcement of Treasury assistance for the New York money market, and there was a rise of fractions to well over a dollar parity. Unions close to nght at 191 1.4 as compared with 194 ¾ last Friday New York Central at 146 as against 149 and Readings at 76 ½ against 78 ¾.
Egyptians.

The Egyptian market has again been exceedingly idle during the past week and the business that has been done has been ona small scale. This was partly due to your side being closed for a few days. There have been few points of interest and the movements on balance are neither numerous, nor, for the most part important. National Banks show a slight decline on the week and close 26 5/8 while Delta Preference and Delta Lands have slightly advanced. Khedividal Mail Steamship have been enquired for , but few shares have changed hands. Egyptian Estates close from without change at 1 18/16 - 15/16 and Corporation of Western Egypt at ¾ premium. Agricultural Banks show no change at 9 13/14 15/16 and Egyptian Markets at 1 1/3. Other Industrials remain firm, but the market is phenomenally idel.
Mining.

The South African market has had another week of fulness, but it is now satisfactory to note a rather better undertone, and dealers in theses shares hope this may soon develop into an active revival. The leading Rhodesians have again chiefly profited by this alight return of animation and Tanganyikas yesterday received good support the price improving to 6 11/15, a gain of 3/8. They close tonight at 6 ¾. chartered and Bankets have also been in demand.
In the Jaffir section Goldfields recovered 3/32 to 3 15/16 and Raud Mines were buyers at 6 1/15. The latent quotation for these are 3 15/16 and 6 1/14.

There no changes to report in the Egyptian sesction, the shares remaining quietly firm awaiting the arrival of the "Season," when they may be expected to take a new lease of life. Nile Valleys close at 6. United Africans at 1 9/16 and Egyptian Mines at 3a.6d. Um Rus are still at the lowest possible point, but these will doubtless share in the upward movement that is sure to come during the next few weeks.

div.head: Commerical and Financial Supplement
div.p: of the
"Egyptian Gazette."

The Commerical and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reivews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the lastest statistic up to the evening of the preceeding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusdive of postage in Egypt. for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particular apply to the Manager "Egyptian Gazette."

div.head: FRESKEL.
div.p: WHAT IT IS
FRESKEL is a dry powdered preparation for Wall and Ceiling Decoration, made ready for use with the addition of water.
It is easily prepared and applied.
WHAT IT DOES
FRESKEL, covers well, and works easy Does not crack, peel, or show brush marks. Does not rub off.
ECONOMICAL - EFFECTIVE.
